The use of an adhesive retention suture (ARS) device (HEMIGARD® ARS 104 device; SUTUREGARD® Medical Inc.; Portland OR) has been previously reported to help 105 bolster fragile skin during wound closure under tension. 5 This ARS device is a low cost FDA 106 registered Class I suture retention device that bolsters the skin to allow high suture tension 107 without ripping the skin. We elected to use this ARS device with retention suture as the main 108 support for many of our wound closures prior to COVID-19, so that patients could -year-old female with a history of diabetes and hypertension presented for Mohs 113 micrographic surgery on a recurrent invasive squamous cell carcinoma, previously treated with 114 cryotherapy. The tumor was cleared with one stage, but the resulting defect measured 2.0 cm 115 wide by 2.4 cm long on her right cheek bordering on the lower eyelid (Fig 1) and was unable to 116 be apposed to allow linear closure. In order to avoid a flap and eliminate the patient's need for 117 post-op suture removal, we used the ARS to bolster the skin around the wound. One ARS strip is 118 placed on each side of the wound with the reinforced and water-resistant holes facing the wound. 119 A 2-0 nylon retention suture was placed through a hole on each side and was used to appose the 120 wound edges under tension. With the wound on either side of the ARS device now apposed and 121 under minimal tension, absorbable dermal interrupted 4-0 Vicryl and superficial 5-0 fast 122absorbing gut sutures were used to finish the closure(Fig 2). After allowing the wound to heal 123 for seven days, the patient removed the ARS device and single central 2-0 Nylon suture at home 124(Fig 3). Patient tolerated the device well and appreciated that the ARS device limited the 125 tendency for potential skin ripping.

It is early in our understanding of the epidemiology of SARS-COV-2, and it is unclear 159 what type of immunity is provided to previously infected individuals or if a second wave of cases 160 may develop over the coming months. 3,6 Therefore, it is important that our patients be able to 161 remove their own sutures to eliminate further patient visits for COVID-19 avoidance and 162 decreased spread, patient convenience, and reduction of health care provider-patient interaction. 163 For example, our patient in case two lives hours away from the office, making at-home suture 164 removal especially appealing. Providing patients with the convenience of removing sutures at 165 home saves time, personal protective equipment and health care associated costs.

FIGREF8.text: combine to result in easier removal of the retention suture by the patient with the 168 ARS device. First, the ARS device, which is approximately 30 thousandths of an inch thick,169    slightly elevates the suture above the skin surface. This eliminates the problem of ingrown170    sutures, which would significantly complicate patient removal. Ingrown sutures can lead to 171 complications such as increased patient pain, wound bleeding, incomplete suture removal and 172 possibly wound dehiscence. 7 Second, the large bite retention suture, over the course of two 173 weeks of retention, will gradually stretch out, making it easier to get the scissors underneath the 174 circle of suture. In our case, the patient had only large scissors but was still able to easily cut the 175 retention suture.176Other techniques for wound closure can also be considered which have decreased in-office 178 follow up such as topical adhesives or fast absorbing gut suture. We believe that use of these 179 alone without the ARS device would not provide effective closure for wounds under high180 tension. Previous studies have found similar cosmetic outcomes between cyanoacrylate and fast 181 absorbing gut for closure of linear wounds on the face, but other studies found fast absorbing gut 182 was superior to cyanoacrylate for linear closures of high tension wounds on the trunk and 183 extremities. 8,9 The use of fast absorbing gut is limited by tensile strength which is maintained for 184 about five days leading to an increased risk for wound dehiscence especially on fragile skin 185 under tension. The high inflammatory tissue response to fast gut should also be considered as 186 this can be distressing to patients and affect the cosmetic outcome. 8 In contrast the to ARS, other 187 adhesive closure devices such as Clozex, (Clozex Medical Inc; Wellesley, MA) and Zip Surgical 188 (Strkyer Corporation; Kalamazoo, MI) are meant to provide only superficial wound support. 189 They are meant to be used on wounds that have tension reduced with some other closure 190 technique (e.g. standard buried absorbable sutures, barbed sutures or retention sutures). We have 191 not done cases in which we combined the ARS with Clozex, Zip Surgical or other superficial 192 closure device. When we have omitted superficial absorbable sutures, we have successfully used 193 acrylate glue for superficial wound support. Acrylate glue has the added benefit of reduced 194 wound exudate to reduce wound care.195 196We have used the ARS on over 50 wounds with no cases developing a contact allergy or 197 intolerance to the adhesive. We advise most patients keep the wound clean and dry post-198 operatively. Patients routinely tell us that the device is well-tolerated and gives them a sense of 199 security that the skin will not tear. A controlled study comparing the use of the ARS device to 200 suture alone on leg excisional wounds will provide clarity on reduction of wound be particularly difficult to manage in terms of dermatologic surgery as it 204 may contribute to delayed wound healing and an increased risk for skin tearing. 10205The ARS device has previously been shown to be beneficial in decreasing the tension across 206 wounds and allowing for closure of fragile skin with good cosmetic results. 5 The ARS device is 207 typically left in place 14-21 days prior to removal, thus providing additional support during the 208 important initial weeks of wound healing. Over the next few months, as dermatologic surgeons 209 adjust to the constant changing of our practice due to COVID-19, we hope that the method 210 outlined in this case series give providers and patients additional tools for wound closure. TABREF1.text: At the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic, prior to the state orders and determination of consensus guidelines, our practice was concerned about our patients' need to return to clinic after surgery for superficial suture removal. Given that majority of our patients are elderly and many have underlying comorbidities, they are considered to be in the most vulnerable population for increased fatality to coronavirus. We sought to use wound closure methods that would adequately support their wound and reduce our need to have physical contact with them. 3,4 We considered different wound closure techniques depending on the size of the wound.
